a.xlink:title: class Organization Domain model for a generic system to manage decision making within an organization. The requirements are at the bottom of the file. View this using options / GVClassDiagram to get a nice layout. UML Class diagram written in Umple The organization
String name
class DecisionMakingBody A committee or individual decision maker OK to just call this Committee
String name

Organization 1 -- * DecisionMakingBody
A DecisionMakingBody called decisionMakingBodies has An Organization. It must always have exactly, one, and can never have none. And there is an upper bound of at most one Organization.
An Organization has some DecisionMakingBodys called decisionMakingBodies. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
When a DecisionMakingBody is created, its Organization must be assigned. When a DecisionMakingBody is deleted, its Organization is not deleted and its list of DecisionMakingBodys is decreased. When an Organization is deleted, its DecisionMakingBodys are not deleted. They are assigned to another Organization.

Organization 1 -- * DecisionMakingBody
A DecisionMakingBody called decisionMakingBodies has An Organization. It must always have exactly, one, and can never have none. And there is an upper bound of at most one Organization.
An Organization has some DecisionMakingBodys called decisionMakingBodies. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
When a DecisionMakingBody is created, its Organization must be assigned. When a DecisionMakingBody is deleted, its Organization is not deleted and its list of DecisionMakingBodys is decreased. When an Organization is deleted, its DecisionMakingBodys are not deleted. They are assigned to another Organization.

Organization 1 -- * DecisionMakingBody
A DecisionMakingBody called decisionMakingBodies has An Organization. It must always have exactly, one, and can never have none. And there is an upper bound of at most one Organization.
An Organization has some DecisionMakingBodys called decisionMakingBodies. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
When a DecisionMakingBody is created, its Organization must be assigned. When a DecisionMakingBody is deleted, its Organization is not deleted and its list of DecisionMakingBodys is decreased. When an Organization is deleted, its DecisionMakingBodys are not deleted. They are assigned to another Organization.
class Decision A formal decision that is proposed or made
String id Formal identification code
Boolean isBeingConsidered True if still in progress; false if dropped or merged/split

Organization 1 -- * Decision
A Decision has An Organization. It must always have exactly, one, and can never have none. And there is an upper bound of at most one Organization.
An Organization has some Decisions. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
When a Decision is created, its Organization must be assigned. When a Decision is deleted, its Organization is not deleted and its list of Decisions is decreased. When an Organization is deleted, its Decisions are not deleted. They are assigned to another Organization.

Organization 1 -- * Decision
A Decision has An Organization. It must always have exactly, one, and can never have none. And there is an upper bound of at most one Organization.
An Organization has some Decisions. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
When a Decision is created, its Organization must be assigned. When a Decision is deleted, its Organization is not deleted and its list of Decisions is decreased. When an Organization is deleted, its Decisions are not deleted. They are assigned to another Organization.

Organization 1 -- * Decision
A Decision has An Organization. It must always have exactly, one, and can never have none. And there is an upper bound of at most one Organization.
An Organization has some Decisions. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
When a Decision is created, its Organization must be assigned. When a Decision is deleted, its Organization is not deleted and its list of Decisions is decreased. When an Organization is deleted, its Decisions are not deleted. They are assigned to another Organization.
class Person
String name

Organization 1 -- * users Person
A Person called users has An Organization. It must always have exactly, one, and can never have none. And there is an upper bound of at most one Organization.
An Organization has some Persons called users. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
When a Person is created, its Organization must be assigned. When a Person is deleted, its Organization is not deleted and its list of Persons is decreased. When an Organization is deleted, its Persons are not deleted. They are assigned to another Organization.

DecisionMakingBody * subordinateBodies -- 0..1 superiorBody DecisionMakingBody
A DecisionMakingBody called superiorBody has some DecisionMakingBodys called subordinateBodies. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
A DecisionMakingBody called subordinateBodies may have a DecisionMakingBody called superiorBody. It can have none or just 1.

DecisionMakingBody * subordinateBodies -- 0..1 superiorBody DecisionMakingBody
A DecisionMakingBody called superiorBody has some DecisionMakingBodys called subordinateBodies. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
A DecisionMakingBody called subordinateBodies may have a DecisionMakingBody called superiorBody. It can have none or just 1.

A DecisionMakingBody called superiorBody has some DecisionMakingBodys called subordinateBodies. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
A DecisionMakingBody called subordinateBodies may have a DecisionMakingBody called superiorBody. It can have none or just 1.
class Membership
Date startDate
Date endDate

DecisionMakingBody 1 -- * Membership
A Membership has A DecisionMakingBody. It must always have exactly, one, and can never have none. And there is an upper bound of at most one DecisionMakingBody.
A DecisionMakingBody has some Memberships. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
When a Membership is created, its DecisionMakingBody must be assigned. When a Membership is deleted, its DecisionMakingBody is not deleted and its list of Memberships is decreased. When a DecisionMakingBody is deleted, its Memberships are not deleted. They are assigned to another DecisionMakingBody.

A DecisionMakingBody has some Memberships. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
When a Membership is created, its DecisionMakingBody must be assigned. When a Membership is deleted, its DecisionMakingBody is not deleted and its list of Memberships is decreased. When a DecisionMakingBody is deleted, its Memberships are not deleted. They are assigned to another DecisionMakingBody.

When a Membership is created, its DecisionMakingBody must be assigned. When a Membership is deleted, its DecisionMakingBody is not deleted and its list of Memberships is decreased. When a DecisionMakingBody is deleted, its Memberships are not deleted. They are assigned to another DecisionMakingBody.

class ApprovalLevel Identifies a level of approval -- e.g. departmental, board level It would be acceptable just to have string attributes instead of associations to this Could also be called ImportanceLevel
String description

DecisionMakingBody * -- 1 ApprovalLevel
An ApprovalLevel has some DecisionMakingBodys called decisionMakingBodies. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
A DecisionMakingBody called decisionMakingBodies has An ApprovalLevel. It must always have exactly, one, and can never have none. And there is an upper bound of at most one ApprovalLevel.
When a DecisionMakingBody is created, its ApprovalLevel must be assigned. When a DecisionMakingBody is deleted, its ApprovalLevel is not deleted and its list of DecisionMakingBodys is decreased. When an ApprovalLevel is deleted, its DecisionMakingBodys are not deleted. They are assigned to another ApprovalLevel.

A Decision called successors has some Decisions called predecessors. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
A Decision called predecessors has some Decisions called successors. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.

class DecisionByBody Tracks the progress of a decision as it is approved and changed
Date dateOfDecision Null of not yet made
Boolean accepted false if not approved and would have to go back down

Decision 1 -- 0..1 currentStatus DecisionByBody
A DecisionByBody called currentStatus has A Decision. It must always have exactly, one, and can never have none. And there is an upper bound of at most one Decision.
A Decision may have a DecisionByBody called currentStatus. It can have none or just 1.

A DecisionByBody called currentStatus has A Decision. It must always have exactly, one, and can never have none. And there is an upper bound of at most one Decision.

A Decision may have a DecisionByBody called currentStatus. It can have none or just 1.
class DecisionType Categorization of decisions
String description

Decision * -- 1 DecisionType
A DecisionType has some Decisions. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
A Decision has A DecisionType. It must always have exactly, one, and can never have none. And there is an upper bound of at most one DecisionType.
When a Decision is created, its DecisionType must be assigned. When a Decision is deleted, its DecisionType is not deleted and its list of Decisions is decreased. When a DecisionType is deleted, its Decisions are not deleted. They are assigned to another DecisionType.

A Decision called onlyApprovedConditionalOnDecision has some DecisionByBodys called decisionByBodies. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.

String filename put filename here, but could be in Document

A DecisionByBody called usedInDecision has some DocumentVersions called documentsForDecision. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.

A DocumentVersion called documentsForDecision has some DecisionByBodys called usedInDecision. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.

A DocumentVersion called documentsForDecision has some DecisionByBodys called usedInDecision. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.

class ChangeRequest Requirements for the above Many organization have decisions to make that are made by various committees in a hierarchical manner. Committees exist at various levels. For example, there might be a departmental committee that makes a decision, and passes the decision up to a division council for further approval, and that then passes the result to the board of directors for final approval. Some committees might consist of a single individual, e.g. a department head or director. The system you will model needs to be able to handle any kind of organization; the committees or individuals will have different names in each organization. In a university, for example, there might be many levels: Department curriculum committee, department council, faculty curriculum committee, faculty council, undergraduate council and Senate. Decisions are of various types, with each type having an importance levels. Based on its importance, a decision only needs to be approved up to a certain level in the hierarchy. For example, the decision about which courses to offer in a given year might only need to be approved by the department curriculum committee, but a new program of studies might need to be approved by the Senate (and every level from department curriculum committee up to Senate). In a company, an expense less than $1000 might need approval by a department head. Expenses of over $1000000 might need approval by the Board of Directors. Each decision has a 'short summary' that describes the decision. Examples might be: 'Purchase Photocopier model AB309 from Xerox for $2570' or 'Create course SEG2104 with title: "Model driven development", and description: 'Model driven development using Umple', and prerequisites: "SEG2105"' Short summaries can have multiple versions (as changes are made). Each decision has associated with it a set of documents. Each document has an id, a filename, a type (MS Word, Excel, Pdf etc.) and a set of versions. When a committee approves a decision, it does so by approving the short summary, and possibly modifying the set of documents by adding new versions of existing documents or adding new documents. A committee might turn down a decision based on one version of a document and request a list of change requests that are simple blocks of text. Users or other committees may add comments to the change requests and may create new versions of documents and an updated version of the short summary. A decision may therefore go up the hierarchy, be rejected, come back down for revisions, go back up again, back down again, and eventually be approved at the highest needed level, or rejected or dropped at any level. It is also possible for a committee to split a decision into separate decisions, or merge two decisions together, or approve one decision conditional on approval of one or more other decisions. Committees have members. Each member has a start and end date on the committee. Each document has a set of authors. Each version has a date and a set of authors.

DecisionByBody 0..1 -> * ChangeRequest
A ChangeRequest may have a DecisionByBody. It can have none or just 1.
A DecisionByBody has some ChangeRequests. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.

DecisionByBody 0..1 -> * ChangeRequest
A ChangeRequest may have a DecisionByBody. It can have none or just 1.
A DecisionByBody has some ChangeRequests. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.

A ChangeRequest may have a DecisionByBody. It can have none or just 1.
A DecisionByBody has some ChangeRequests. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
class Document
String id
String docType

Document 1 -- * versions DocumentVersion
A DocumentVersion called versions has A Document. It must always have exactly, one, and can never have none. And there is an upper bound of at most one Document.
A Document has some DocumentVersions called versions. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
When a DocumentVersion is created, its Document must be assigned. When a DocumentVersion is deleted, its Document is not deleted and its list of DocumentVersions is decreased. When a Document is deleted, its DocumentVersions are not deleted. They are assigned to another Document.

Document 1 -- * versions DocumentVersion
A DocumentVersion called versions has A Document. It must always have exactly, one, and can never have none. And there is an upper bound of at most one Document.
A Document has some DocumentVersions called versions. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
When a DocumentVersion is created, its Document must be assigned. When a DocumentVersion is deleted, its Document is not deleted and its list of DocumentVersions is decreased. When a Document is deleted, its DocumentVersions are not deleted. They are assigned to another Document.

Document 1 -- * versions DocumentVersion
A DocumentVersion called versions has A Document. It must always have exactly, one, and can never have none. And there is an upper bound of at most one Document.
A Document has some DocumentVersions called versions. It can have none, and there is no upper bound defined.
When a DocumentVersion is created, its Document must be assigned. When a DocumentVersion is deleted, its Document is not deleted and its list of DocumentVersions is decreased. When a Document is deleted, its DocumentVersions are not deleted. They are assigned to another Document.
